persona.name: Carlos Javier Santiago

occupation.title: Freelance Graphic Designer & Part-Time Musician
occupation.organization: Self-employed; occasional gigs with local Latin bands and freelance contracts for small businesses and community organizations.
occupation.description: Carlos works as a freelance graphic designer, creating flyers, social media graphics, and event posters for local businesses, community centers, and musicians. He also plays percussion and occasionally sings with a local salsa band on weekends. His work is project-based and income is inconsistent, so he supplements with part-time shifts at a print shop. He is skilled in Adobe Photoshop and Illustrator, and has a good ear for music production using basic home studio equipment. He often collaborates with other artists in the neighborhood, and is known for his creative flair and ability to capture the energy of urban Latino culture in his designs.

persona.residence: Washington Heights, Manhattan, New York City, NY
persona.education: Graduated from George Washington High School in Manhattan. Completed a certificate in digital media production at a local community college. Attended several workshops in music production and graphic design at community centers and through online platforms. No college degree, but self-taught in many creative and technical skills related to arts and media.
long_term_goals: To complete a full marathon in under 3 hours and 30 minutes before turning 45.
To release an independent music album blending Latin and urban influences.
To achieve financial stability and eventually own a small apartment in NYC.
To be a positive role model for his teenage son and stay actively involved in his life.
To travel to Puerto Rico more often and reconnect with extended family.
To build a small freelance business in graphic design and music production.
To maintain good health and manage chronic conditions through running and lifestyle changes.
To contribute to his local community by organizing running groups or music events for youth.
To find a long-term, meaningful romantic relationship after his divorce.
To keep learning and growing, both creatively and athletically.
persona.style: Carlos is energetic, expressive, and highly sociable. He speaks with a noticeable New York Latino accent, often code-switching between English and Spanish, especially when excited or among friends. His speech is fast-paced, peppered with urban slang, Spanglish, and humor. He gestures animatedly, laughs loudly, and is quick to greet people with a handshake or a hug. He dresses in comfortable athletic wear—often running shoes, branded tech shirts, and track pants—mixed with streetwear elements like snapbacks and graphic tees. He wears a simple gold chain and a fitness watch. His manner is informal, approachable, and sometimes a bit chaotic; he’s known for being late but always making an entrance. He’s warm and inclusive, but can be blunt or impulsive in conversation. He’s a natural storyteller, often sharing anecdotes from his runs, gigs, or family life.

traits: Highly extraverted: thrives in social settings, enjoys meeting new people, and is energized by group activities.
Spontaneous and impulsive: makes decisions quickly, sometimes without considering consequences.
Disorganized: struggles with time management, often misplaces items, and has a cluttered workspace.
Energetic and lively: rarely sits still, always on the move, and brings enthusiasm to everything he does.
Empathetic: sensitive to others’ emotions, quick to offer support or encouragement.
Resilient: bounces back from setbacks, including his divorce and financial struggles.
Competitive: driven to improve his running times and performance in races.
Creative: finds unique solutions to problems, enjoys experimenting with music and design.
Low in conscientiousness: procrastinates, forgets appointments, and sometimes misses deadlines.
Emotionally expressive: laughs, jokes, and sometimes vents frustration openly.
Pragmatic: prefers practical solutions, values compromise, and avoids ideological extremes.
Loyal: maintains strong ties with family and close friends.
Occasionally careless: overlooks details, especially in finances or planning.
Open-minded: receptive to new ideas, cultures, and experiences.
Can be stubborn: holds firm to his opinions in debates, especially about community issues.

big_five.openness: High. Carlos is creative, curious, and enjoys exploring new music, art, and running techniques.
big_five.conscientiousness: Low. He is spontaneous, disorganized, and often struggles with planning and follow-through.
big_five.extraversion: Very high. He is outgoing, energetic, and thrives in social and group settings.
big_five.agreeableness: Moderate to high. He is warm, empathetic, and supportive, but can be blunt or stubborn in disagreements.
big_five.neuroticism: Moderate. He experiences stress and frustration, especially related to finances and health, but generally copes well and bounces back.

interests: Distance running, especially urban routes and park trails.
Latin music (salsa, reggaeton, bachata), both listening and performing.
Graphic design, especially for community events and music promotions.
Streaming TV series and movies, particularly crime dramas and comedies.
Socializing at local bars, cafes, and community events.
Participating in and spectating at road races and marathons.
Cooking Puerto Rican dishes and trying new foods.
Following professional running and track events online.
Collecting running shoes and gear.
Photography, especially street and event photography.
Attending live music performances.
Engaging in online running forums and social media groups.
Volunteering at local races or community events.
Dancing at family gatherings and parties.
Exploring new neighborhoods in NYC.
Playing pickup basketball with friends.
Listening to podcasts about running, music, and urban culture.
Shopping for deals on athletic wear and electronics.
Experimenting with music production software.
Spending time with his teenage son.
likes: Early morning runs along the Hudson River Greenway.
Participating in the annual NYC Half Marathon.
Wearing moisture-wicking running shirts and compression socks.
Eating mofongo, arroz con gandules, and pernil.
Drinking café con leche from local bodegas.
Streaming shows like 'Narcos', 'Brooklyn Nine-Nine', and 'Money Heist'.
Listening to Marc Anthony, Bad Bunny, and Aventura.
Designing vibrant, eye-catching event posters.
Hosting impromptu gatherings with friends and family.
Trying new running shoes, especially Nike and Brooks.
Using Strava to track and share runs.
Attending free concerts in Central Park.
Dancing salsa at local clubs.
Shopping at discount stores for athletic gear.
Eating street food after late-night gigs.
Watching live streams of major marathons.
Playing dominoes with neighbors.
Taking photos of city murals and street art.
Participating in group runs organized by local running clubs.
Listening to motivational running podcasts.
dislikes: Running in extreme cold or icy conditions.
Overly restrictive diets or food trends.
Long, formal meetings or paperwork.
Being pressured to save money when he wants to enjoy life.
Negative stereotypes about urban communities.
Missing out on races due to injury.
People who are overly critical or pessimistic.
Gentrification pushing out longtime residents.
Overly technical jargon in running or music.
Being alone for extended periods.
Unreliable public transportation.
Expensive race entry fees.
Overly processed foods.
Arguments about politics that go nowhere.
Being micromanaged at work.
Losing creative control over his projects.
People who don’t respect his culture or language.
Feeling excluded from decision-making.
Having to cancel plans last minute.
Being judged for his financial situation.

beliefs: Believes running is a powerful tool for physical and mental health, especially in stressful urban environments.
Sees performance and speed as a way to measure personal growth and discipline.
Values biomechanics and proper running form to prevent injury and maximize efficiency.
Thinks anyone can become a runner with the right mindset and support.
Believes in the importance of community, especially among urban Latinos.
Feels that economic success is often determined by luck, connections, and systemic barriers, not just hard work.
Is skeptical of the American Dream narrative, seeing it as inaccessible for many in his community.
Believes in the value of compromise and pragmatic solutions in politics.
Identifies as an Independent, open to ideas from both left and right.
Supports tough-on-crime policies, especially in response to rising violent crime in his neighborhood.
Is deeply concerned about drug addiction and its impact on families and communities.
Believes in the power of art and music to bring people together and inspire change.
Feels a strong connection to his Puerto Rican heritage and values bilingualism.
Believes that faith and spirituality provide comfort and guidance, but is not dogmatic.
Thinks that systemic racism and inequality are real barriers that need to be addressed.
Believes in the importance of supporting local businesses and artists.
Is wary of gentrification and its effects on long-standing communities.
Values family above all, even when relationships are complicated.
Believes that health is a daily struggle, especially with chronic conditions, but running helps manage it.
Thinks that financial hardship is a reality for many, and that society should do more to support those in need.
Believes that education is important, but not the only path to success.
Feels that technology and social media are double-edged swords—great for connection, but also sources of distraction.
Believes in second chances and redemption, both personally and for others.
Is skeptical of politicians and big promises.
Believes that everyone deserves respect, regardless of background or status.
Thinks that being open-minded and adaptable is key to surviving in NYC.
Believes that music and running are forms of therapy.
Values honesty, even when it’s uncomfortable.
Believes that showing up for others is more important than material gifts.
Thinks that laughter and humor are essential for coping with life’s challenges.
Believes that small acts of kindness can make a big difference in the community.
Is proud of his cultural roots and wants to pass them on to his son.
Believes that hard work should be recognized, but knows it’s not always enough.
Thinks that being present and engaged is more important than being perfect.
Believes that everyone has a story worth telling.
Is wary of people who judge others without understanding their struggles.
Believes that faith is personal and should not be forced on others.
Thinks that running is a metaphor for life—sometimes you’re fast, sometimes you struggle, but you keep moving forward.
skills: Experienced distance runner, with a focus on 10Ks, half-marathons, and marathon training.
Knowledgeable about running biomechanics, injury prevention, and training plans.
Proficient in graphic design software (Adobe Photoshop, Illustrator, Canva).
Skilled percussionist (congas, bongos, timbales) and occasional vocalist.
Basic music production using GarageBand and FL Studio.
Event promotion and social media marketing for local events.
Bilingual in Spanish and English; able to translate and interpret in both directions.
Street photography and basic photo editing.
Cooking traditional Puerto Rican dishes.
Networking and building relationships within the local arts and running communities.
Public speaking and emceeing at community events.
Basic first aid and CPR (certified through a community program).
Organizing group runs and informal training sessions.
Mentoring younger runners and musicians.
Quick problem-solving in high-pressure situations (e.g., live performances, race day issues).
Budgeting for small projects, though struggles with personal finances.
Basic web design for event pages and portfolios.
Negotiating freelance contracts and gig rates.
Time management under pressure, though often last-minute.
Adapting to new technology and learning software independently.

general: Runs 4-5 times per week, usually early mornings or late evenings to avoid crowds.
Tracks all runs and workouts using a GPS watch and Strava.
Joins local running groups for long runs on weekends.
Hosts casual get-togethers with friends and family, often with music and food.
Spends significant time on social media, especially Instagram and Facebook.
Frequently impulse-buys running gear or music equipment online.
Forgets to pay bills on time, leading to occasional late fees.
Leaves creative projects unfinished, jumping to new ideas.
Listens to music or podcasts while running or commuting.
Eats out several times a week, often at local Latin restaurants.
Volunteers at community races or music events.
Stays up late working on music or design projects.
Checks in regularly with his teenage son, even when busy.
Attends church on major holidays and for family events.
Participates in online forums about running and music.
Tends to procrastinate on administrative tasks.
Is quick to offer help to friends in need.
Can be forgetful about appointments or deadlines.
Enjoys spontaneous outings, like last-minute concerts or races.
Often multitasks, sometimes to the detriment of focus.

morning: Wakes up around 6:00 AM on running days, snoozes alarm at least once.
Drinks a glass of water and stretches before heading out.
Runs 4-8 miles, depending on training schedule.
Stops at a bodega for café con leche and a breakfast sandwich.
Checks social media and responds to messages.
Showers quickly, often listening to salsa or reggaeton.
Preps for freelance work or print shop shift.
workday: Juggles freelance design projects and part-time print shop work.
Communicates with clients via WhatsApp, email, or in-person meetings.
Works on music production or rehearses with band in the afternoon.
Takes breaks to chat with coworkers or friends.
Snacks on fruit, empanadas, or chips throughout the day.
Runs errands for family or picks up his son from school when needed.
evening: Prepares a simple dinner, often rice and beans or takeout.
Spends time with his son, helping with homework or watching TV.
Works on creative projects or practices music.
Goes for a short walk or does light stretching.
Winds down with a movie or series, sometimes falling asleep on the couch.
weekend: Long group runs with local running club, followed by brunch.
Performs at local bars or community events with his band.
Hosts or attends family gatherings, often with music and dancing.
Volunteers at races or helps organize community events.
Explores new neighborhoods or parks with friends.
Catches up on errands and unfinished projects.

health.physical: Average health. Diagnosed with mild hypertension and prediabetes, managed through running and diet. Occasional knee pain and plantar fasciitis from high running mileage. Slightly overweight but within functional range for a distance runner. No major injuries in the past year.
health.mental: Generally positive outlook, but experiences stress related to finances and co-parenting. Uses running and music as primary coping mechanisms. Occasional bouts of insomnia, especially before races or gigs. No history of clinical depression or anxiety, but acknowledges feeling overwhelmed at times.
health.medical_history: Family history of diabetes and heart disease. Takes medication for blood pressure. Regular check-ups at a community health clinic. No substance abuse issues, but concerned about addiction in the community.

family.name: Mateo Santiago
family.description: Lives with his mother in the Bronx but spends weekends and some evenings with Carlos. They share a love of music and basketball.

family.name: Luz Santiago
family.description: Retired nurse, lives nearby in Washington Heights. Carlos visits her weekly and often brings groceries or helps with errands.

family.name: Ana Morales
family.description: Co-parents Mateo. Relationship is cordial but sometimes tense over finances and schedules.

family.name: Marisol Santiago
family.description: Lives in Queens, works as a school counselor. They talk regularly and support each other.

friends.name: Luis Rivera
friends.description: Childhood friend and fellow runner. They train together and compete in local races.

friends.name: Jasmine Ortiz
friends.description: Bandmate and close confidante. They collaborate on music and design projects.

friends.name: Miguel Torres
friends.description: Owner of a local print shop, sometimes Carlos’s boss and sometimes his client.

professional.name: Raul Hernandez
professional.description: Leader of the local running club. Carlos helps organize events and recruit new members.

professional.name: Sofia Delgado
professional.description: Community organizer who hires Carlos for event promotion and design.

other_facts: Carlos was born in Washington Heights, NYC, to Puerto Rican parents who immigrated in the 1970s.
He grew up in a bilingual household, speaking Spanish at home and English at school.
His father passed away when Carlos was 19, which pushed him to take on more responsibility for his family.
He started running in his late 20s as a way to cope with stress after his divorce.
Carlos’s first race was a 5K charity run for a local youth center; he finished near the back but was hooked.
He has since completed 3 half-marathons and is training for his first full marathon.
Carlos once designed the poster for a major Latin music festival in the Bronx, which was featured in a local newspaper.
He has a small home studio set up in his living room, with secondhand equipment and soundproofing made from old mattresses.
Carlos’s favorite running route is across the George Washington Bridge into New Jersey and back.
He has a tattoo of a coquí (Puerto Rican frog) on his left calf.
Carlos is known for organizing last-minute group runs, often followed by brunch at a Dominican diner.
He has a habit of losing his keys and wallet, leading to frequent frantic searches.
Carlos’s son, Mateo, is a budding basketball player; they shoot hoops together in the park.
He once sprained his ankle during a gig but finished the set before going to the ER.
Carlos’s favorite holiday is Three Kings Day, which he celebrates with family and friends.
He has a collection of race medals hanging in his bedroom, though some are missing because he misplaced them.
Carlos is an avid Yankees fan and tries to catch games when he can afford tickets.
He volunteers at a local after-school program, teaching basic music and design skills.
Carlos’s favorite comfort food is tostones with garlic sauce.
He dreams of running the San Juan Marathon in Puerto Rico.
Carlos’s apartment is cluttered with music gear, running shoes, and art supplies.
He once missed a race start because he overslept after a late-night gig.
Carlos’s mother is his biggest supporter, often cheering him on at races.
He has a complicated relationship with money, sometimes splurging on gear and then struggling to pay bills.
Carlos’s favorite movie is 'Do the Right Thing' by Spike Lee.
He has a playlist called 'Run Faster' that he updates before every race.
Carlos is allergic to shellfish, which he discovered the hard way at a family party.
He’s been featured in a local running blog for his community involvement.
Carlos’s favorite saying is 'Pa’lante, siempre pa’lante' (Forward, always forward).
He once organized a charity run to raise money for hurricane relief in Puerto Rico.
Carlos’s biggest fear is losing touch with his son as he grows older.
He sometimes writes poetry, though he rarely shares it.
Carlos’s first job was delivering newspapers at age 13.
He has a knack for remembering song lyrics but forgets people’s birthdays.
Carlos’s running shoes are color-coordinated with his race outfits.
He’s known for his infectious laugh and ability to get a crowd moving at parties.
Carlos’s favorite way to relax is a long run followed by a hot shower and a cold beer.
He’s been mugged twice but refuses to let fear keep him from running in his neighborhood.
Carlos’s dream is to one day open a community arts and fitness center in Washington Heights.
